titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Phil Siekevitz (b. 1918) was a biochemist who received his Ph.D. from the University of California,Berkeley. He worked for many years at the Rockefeller Institute. In 1966 he was President of the American Society of Cell Biology. He was elected to the National Academy of Sciences in 1975 and President of the New York Academy of Sciences in 1976. The Enzyme Club was founded in 1942 as a way for researchers in the developing field of biochemistry to share information. The group met in the facilities of the Rockefeller Institute for 50 years before it was disbanded in 1992. Philip Siekevitz was the group's treasurer and its "prime mover" for over 30 years. The Enzyme Club hosted talks on biochemistry, molecular biology, genetics; their speakers included many Nobel laureates.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of records of the Enzyme Club and papers of Philip Siekevitz. Materials include: a printed history of the club; articles on the club; financial sponsorship documentation; records relating to anniversary celebrations; a list of speakers (1941-1992); and reprints of articles written by Siekevitz and others.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
